Yeah, forget Cenk and Ana for a moment, the issue at hand is the case for 
decriminalising drugs. It's not about vanquishing the world of criminal 
gangs; of course crims will always just move on to more profitable forms of 
crime. However, they'd no longer be able to rake in huge profits from drug 
dealing. This would make many of the social ills associated with the 
enormous and unregulated black market in drugs (rampant violence, 
addiction, deaths from adulterated substances, unnecessary criminalisation 
of users etc) less costly and damaging to society at large, and easier to 
bring under control - as was the case with the ending of alcohol 
prohibition. I hope I've managed to explain my meaning better.

comments.text:
+sharper68 *"Look at what happened with alcohol when we banned it,  trying 
to arrest our way out of this problem is digging in sand."*

That's partly because one didn't go after it with violent enough means 
though. There's no question that prohibition could have worked if one just 
executed everyone who tried to sell or manufacture alcohol. In any case, 
there's another side to this as well, namely that there are/were millions 
of addicts who are so thoroughly immoral that they will fund organized 
crime to get their hits. Such people probably need forced treatment or long 
jail sentences to undermine the black market. Highly public displays of the 
fact that named individuals have their lives ruined by becoming criminals 
is another approach to discourage usage.

The idea that one just have to accept all manner of social ills just 
because certain people have acquired chemical habits is highly defeatist.

In any case, part of the problem here is that the illicit market can take 
root no matter if the substances are legal or not. The reason for this is 
that, when they're highly available, the substances can be used as 
additives in all manner of foods to create compulsive cravings for those 
exact foods in people as the drugs have rewired their brains to repeat 
actions that led to highly pleasurable experiences. When they have those 
cravings, you can sell the foods at ridiculous prices or simply out compete 
your competition by chemically programming consumers. These substances 
really are shit that we don't want readily available in society.

At the same time, one probably wants some alternative punishments, as the 
prison model in the US is very bad as well.
comments.author: Gnomefro

top_comment.text:
Come on legalizing all drugs TYT, really? We are not talking about just 
some pot here. We are talking about drugs like methamphetamines, cocaine, 
heroin, and even bath salts. These things are basically poison, so what 
should we start legalizing ricin and cyanide? Do you realize why 
prohibition was such an epic failure? Because alcohol was a major aspect of 
culture. If you legalize these drugs, the same thing could happen. People 
will start to normalize it and then they'll get addicted. Addicts often 
have a problem simply admitting they have a problem and will not seek help. 
That is why I think rehab for drug offenders needs to be mandatory and drug 
users should have job opportuities and voting rights when they get out of 
jail. Oh and as for Portugal's so called success-there are many countries 
that have not legalized these drugs and have WAAAAAAY lower drug rates than 
Portugal.  So there is another way., ﻿

top_comment.author: BionicDance

comments.text:
+Rebecca Bratt First of all...did I mention I was against marijuana? 
Because I'm not...nearly everyone I know uses or has used it before and I 
couldn't be more fine with that. (other than the scumbags of course) The 
thing I'm getting at is make something *better*, that is literally it. The 
whole synthesizing thing is obviously a complete and utter failure, how 
about the THC oil though? No high, still helps those who need the drug. 
Your comment is quite long, and quite frankly I just don't feel like 
replying to it as it's just a comment...so I will reply in points rather 
than spend the time typing everything out.

1. That sucks that you had to go through all of that, but just because one 
thing worked for you, doesn't mean that's the only thing that can work for 
you. I'm sure if enough time and research is put into your disease a cure 
can be made.

2. Who are you to judge those who you don't know? Those people who I 
described lives *revolved* around marijuana, it revolved around their lives 
so much it seemed as though every word that came out of their mouth was 
related to marijuana in some way. I'm not saying that all those who use the 
drug are like this...because just about everyone I know has used or uses 
the drug, most of them are fine.

3. I've seen successful potheads too, like in the last point...but no where 
near those who you describe. Your grades however, are quite irrelevant, 
good on you though.

4. No I don't think all potheads are lazy, didn't even remotely say or 
insinuate that.

5. Nothing is impossible, that's a fact of life. Existence is literally a 
blank canvas, you can do absolutely anything you want...all you need is the 
resources to do it. Just because this may not be possible *now* doesn't 
mean it's impossible. We cannot currently create stars...does that mean 
it's impossible...og course not. Did you think those synthesized chemicals 
might not be safe because we don't have the understanding to make safe 
synthesized chemicals in the first place?

6. That analogy does make sense...but we're talking about a *theoritical* 
prefect drug vs a natural drug...not some artificial drug that would 
probably cause death. Sure those pharmaceutical companies can't make a drug 
as good as marijuana...but last time I checked Mother Nature was a master 
pharmacologist, geneticist, etc. we however are not.

7. Already aware of the potential of Marijuana, no need to tell me your 
story there, I know it works quite well...which is why I am for medicinal 
use.

8. Just because you've had experience with illness and one thing worked for 
you, doesn't mean you know everything. The simple fact is, in the past 10 
years marijuana was a terrible thing, the general opinion is changing and 
now you can use it...that doesn't make it a miracle drug just because it 
worked while other options failed. The simple fact of the matter is it *can* 
be improved...that that's my whole point.
comments.author: attk master

comments.text:
+nitrohedgehog It is most certainly irrelevant, because there can be better 
alternatives. R and D is expensive...your point? The Human body isn't even 
fully understood in the first place, not to mention the fact that we can do 
absolutely *anything* to it or anything else to get the result we want, 
sure that's quite a ways beyond our abilities...but would that not help for 
say...everything from diseases to conditioning for space flight?

There's that word again...impossible. Just using that word and meaning it 
discredits you right off the bat. *ANY* scientist in his or her right mind 
wouldn't use that word, because there is not one thing that is in any way 
permanently impossible. I'm not, nor did I say marijuana is a bad thing, 
but it's certainly not a miracle either, the point is we can *make* this 
miracle drug, there's no reason not to try. I know many use it daily and 
are healthy, my parents for example, my friends, nearly everyone that I 
went to High School with. The point is, try for better, don't want to see 
scumbags just sitting there smoking pot and draining upon society like the 
leeches they are.
comments.author: attk master

comments.author: nitrohedgehog

comments.text:
+attk master
It is completely irrelevant because of the negatives? Who the FUCK do you 
think you are talking to?!

Because of my autoimmune disease, I have had countless steroid injections, 
low-dose chemotherapy (which we had to discontinue because I lost 10 lbs in 
the last 5 weeks.. too much even with my wisdom teeth removal... which 
resulted in infection because of the methotrexate), I take 13 pills a day, 
have had knee surgery... The methotrexate has even caused hair loss and my 
nails to turn yellow, as well as anemia. I have spent the last 10 years in 
and out of hospitals, trying to be able to chew or walk without struggle 
and pain. I smoke medical marijuana, and take a synthetic marijuana pill 
(nabilone).

The negative effects you go on about tells me, quite frankly, that you have 
surrounded yourself with losers and rather than holding their shortcomings 
against them, you take a lazy cop out. It's easier to blame marijuana than 
poor character. Just like parents that blame the media for their kids 
inability to show empathy. These negatives you talk about are imaginary. 
People don't surround their lives around pot- they surround their lives 
around nothing, and smoke pot while they do it. Don't blame the drug for 
the ignorant people that consume it. You see the same character traits in 
non-potheads just as often.

I have also seen MANY successful potheads. The potheads I am surrounded by 
go to school, go to work... one of the biggest potheads I know is the owner 
of an extremely successful small business, house, vehicle... in his mid 
twenties, with no silver spoon to help him. Through highschool, I have 
smoked weed. Despite being too disabled to have great attendance, I get 
GREAT grades- excluding a midterm, I haven't had a grade below 90% this 
year.

The fact that you think of potheads as lazy, unmotivated individuals says 2 
things. 1) You surround yourself with unmotivated individuals. 2) You 
blindly follow the propaganda that is intended to justify failing drug laws.

Also, the fact that you say "nothing is impossible" to the idea of a 
flawless synthetic drug shows just how ignorant you are on the subject of 
pharmacology. YES, IT IS IMPOSSIBLE! Why the hell do you think they give me 
pills to cope with the effects of pills to cope with the effects of 
injections? Because synthesized chemicals are NOT 100% safe.

They synthesize marijuana because it is ultimately a legal loophole. Big 
pharma can play drug dealer, take a bigger cut, and dodge the law. That's 
it. They synthesize it to make money and make it easier to legally 
distribute.

To say that synthetic is superior is like saying an apple I grew from my 
own tree is not superior to one I buy in the grocery store, full of 
chemicals and oftentimes genetically modified. They're NOT. That's why 
we're encouraged to eat organic. Because natural is best.

When I had my knee surgery, I didn't take any pain killers. They made me 
nauseous. I ONLY used marijuana as pain management... and my doctors said 
that I was managing my pain better than they had expected. When I smoked 
weed once in a while, my disease was out of control. When I started smoking 
for medical rather than recreational reasons, the progression started to 
slow.

The last 10 years of my life have been procedures, pills, injections, I 
have spent days and days out of my life in MRI machines alone... I have 
more experience with the reality of illness and medications than most 
people experience in a lifetime. Honestly, I don't know who the fuck you 
think you are, but you need to shut up. You don't know what you're talking 
about.
comments.author: Rebecca Bratt

comments.text:
+attk master
it's not irrelevant, few others are qualified to research and develop drugs 
of a "perfect" caliber (R&D also costs a shitton of money). everything is 
give and take, you can't make a drug that both give a strong euphoria with 
zero negative side effects, that's not how the human body works. the body 
has to have time to recover from an altered state of mind, good or bad.

that's why it's impossible, it would defy biology itself. futhermore, 
marijuana fills this gap already with minimal side effects. many use it 
daily and are healthy, productive citizens (willie nelson is 70+ and STILL 
touring). you'd be hard pressed to find someone who wants to spend millions 
improving on something when the bar is already set so high
